102.description: This talk is about to better understand developer experience with Application Platform a Service (aPaaS). I will share our research driven as well industry collaboration effort for supporting developers to describe, predict, and possible prescribe their development behaviors on aPaaS. Novelty in our work is to employ all metadata actions recorded on aPaaS (that is, digital trace for software development) and model them as a complex system using graph theory, which is successfully employed in network science. I’ll show with a real life software development case on aPaaS where the developer’s behavior is characterized with signature patternsthat can be associated with some best practices and/or software engineering patterns. Network science approach to developer behavior analysis utilizing digital trace data may eventually help us to radically change the way of thinking and working for software development.
102.title: PAAS Üzerinde Metadata Kullanarak Ağ Bilimi Temelli Geliştirici Davranış Analizi

103.description: Contactless payment infrastructure with HCE in Android
103.title: Mobile Payment with HCE

104.description: In this talk we’ll take a look at the Android Support Libraries available to community, and some of the components you can use from them. We’ll also take a dive into important features with examples on how to implement to your app.
104.title: The Android Support Library

105.description: The way we interact with our devices is changing rapidly. Things that we, till now, took for granted like the UI are now optional and the need to talk back to your users becomes a necessity if you want to keep your app and your business on the edge of technology. In this talk you'll learn about Google's new conversational user experience platform, API.ai and you'll get familiar with its platform and tools.
105.title: Ok Google, we need to talk!

106.description: Review of new Firebase features; Overview of Cloud Functions; Using Cloud Functions for extending the backend capabilities, examples; Interaction with third-party services; Dynamic hosting on Firebase using Cloud Functions; Example of using Google Assistent on the backend with Cloud Functions; What is better to use? Cloud Functions or AWS Lambda. Advantages and disadvantages
106.title: Firebase Cloud Functions: New opportunities of serverless backend.

107.description: Javascript revolution continues with new language features, new tools, libraries and frameworks taking their part at the ecosystem. In this session, we'll start with the current state of the javascript to give an overview and then cover the major players at the UI tier; Angular, React, Vue and Web Components to see how they stack up against each other. This talk is a good opportunity to catch up with the latest trends in web and see where we are headed next.
107.title: State of the JavaScript UI Landscape

108.description: I would like to talk shortly about the domain of Computer Vision. Current state of art and its connection with deep learning.  What kind of projects can we have to impact our future and how the future machines look like.I am thinking of making a small demo with tensorflow on computer vision.
108.title: Future with Machine Vision

109.description: Is Flutter the next big thing in creating multiplatform apps. Google seems to think so. So let’s find out if the Flutter lets us create apps for Android and IOS and can keep up with Native apps.
109.title: Dart: I'm your Flutter

110.description: Since the beginning, a UX designers’ job is assisting the user to perform the needed task in the possible shortest time by minimalizing the information and the interface they interacted.  Nowadays, things are a bit different than the past. Now, users don't even have to look for the content to get the answer. The only thing they need to do is talking with a chatbot or a virtual personal assistant which response in seconds! </br>So, for a UX designer, things are tougher than ever. If you look the evolution of the virtual personal assistants and chatbots,  you'll see no interface problems about reaching the content. Let's dive into the magical world of VPAs and chatbots to see how the voice interactions and the conversational UX make our daily life easier than ever.
110.title: Hey Google; Whats Next?

111.description: During this talk you are going to learn how you can improve your Firebase app using Machine Learning. There will be a demo game that uses Cloud Vision Api.
111.title: Machine Learning meets Firebase

112.description: Google I/O 2017'yle beraber herkesin geliştirmesine ve kullanımına açılan Instant App'lerin nasıl geliştirilebileceği hakkında bilgi verilecek.
112.title: Introduction to Android Instant Apps

114.description: Learn about how to use  Cloud functions and Cloud Firestore to build mobile apps, Crashlytics and Performance Monitoring to gain insights into your app's issues and performance.
114.title: Develop your next app with Firebase

115.description: Bots are new apps! With the power of AI (Artificial Intelligence) chatbots provide an enhanced experience for our clients, employees, and partners. Today’s users expect to have real-time information at their fingertips. Chatbots allow the users to get the information they need, when they need it - putting them in control of their digital world. Because of this self-service enablement, there will be a noticeable reduction of operational costs, heightened client satisfaction, and the facilitation of modern user experiences in workflows.
115.title: Building an Intelligent ChatBot with BotFramework and Microsoft Cognitive Services

116.description: The main thought - developers should be able to enjoy their work.</br>Assume you’ve started working on development of the web application. By the time you’ve got to the spot of enjoyable developemt, you would have to go through all the complex details of  building the basement for your app, taking care about the backend, servers and more...Cloud Functions allows Firebase developers to create a backend without having to worry about servers. During the talk you will learn what's possible with Cloud Functions and how it can be used for many different key use cases for your web app and not only. You'll see real world examples that show how Cloud Functions for Firebase is the programmatic glue that allows you to extend and connect Firebase products and cloud services.
116.title: Go beyond the web development with Firebase Cloud Functions

118.description: H2O is a high-available, scalable and light-weight machine learning and deep learning framework. Nowadays it is a big challenge for data scientists and developers to deploy and maintain a machine learning model on production environment. Devops and continuous delivery is also a critical issue for a machine learning product pipeline. In this session development of machine learning model with H2O framework and its devops pipeline will be introduced.
118.title: AI Development with h2o.ai

119.description: Scale Your Web Applications With Kubernetes
119.title: Scale Your Web Applications With Kubernetes

121.description: Docker has had a built in orchestrator for more than one year. It includes health checking, auto failover, scaling, key-value store, load balancing, virtual extensible lan support, IPSec encryption, secret and config management out of the box. In this talk, many of these aspects will be explained with examples and demos. There will be some scenarios discussed about deploying to production. Sample microservices and deployment with Docker Stack YAML files will be examined.
121.title: Docker Swarm Mode

122.description: Writing async code is never easy, but nowadays we have many solutions. One approach would be to use RxJava and its schedulers but... have you heard of Kotlin Coroutines? Join us and let's see how good they are today!
122.title: eAsync Kotlin

123.description: Xamarin Giriş-101, Xamarin Nedir?, Xamarin Forms Nedir?, Kod Yapısı, Geliştirici Araçları ,Xamarin İçeriği, Sayfa Yapıları, Tasarım Yapıları, Kontroller
123.title: Microsoft Xamarin

126.description: Notification channels and badges are part of the many updates in Android O. Starting in Android O, you divide all of your notifications into different notification channels, depending on the type of notification your app is sending. Using channels, you can easily differentiate between different types of communication and provide different default sounds, importance, icons, and more. Once a notification channel exists on the device, users have full control over the settings per notification channel.
126.title: Notification Channel and Badges in Kotlin

127.description: 2 speakers for the price of 1! A step by step guide to all the features Apache NetBeans offers for developers a single, complete solution to create,edit, test and ship code in Java, android, html5, JavaScript and other languages
127.title: Developing, testing and writing better Code with the Apache NetBeans IDE

131.description:
Git is one of the most powerful tool in developers' toolbox. If you use it correctly, it dramatically increases productivity of developers and eliminates the waste products continuously. Developers cultivate a development culture on top Git most of the time.

It's powerful but its power is untamed. Many teams fall into several traps of misusing commands and therefore feel uncomfortable while using Git. We mess up Git history, the codebase and the whole preferred branching strategy in seconds. We use branches, merge/rebase strategies, creating commits in wrong ways. Even we never take committing paradigms into account while using Git.

As a software craftsman, I've been using Git for years and I've already educated Git to hundreds of developers in all levels. I'm so lucky; I had a chance to experience huge amount of anti-patterns in time. In this talk, I will talk about what those anti-patterns are and what should we do in order not to fall into them.
131.title: Git Anti-Patterns: How To Mess Up With Git And Love It Again

132.description: Serving stateless Polymer components over Firebase wit data provided by Firestore
132.title: Components on fire!

133.description:
Testability is what gives developers chills. Most people choose to avoid writing unit tests when it comes to UI elements (especially, things like adapters). When phone status gets involved, things might get even uglier as you need to test your app with different statuses (like Bluetooth on/off). Using Robolectric is a way to play with these options but it increases the run time. While manually testing your app is enough in some cases, it’s time consuming, open to mistakes and won’t allow you to test some corner cases.

In this session, we’ll unit test the components of a screen with a RecyclerView. We’ll spend more time with code than slides and use some testing libraries such as Mockito. The examples will be in Kotlin but I’ll be happy to clarify any part of the session in Java.
133.title: val testival = unitTests as Festival

134.description: How we make the AMP as PWA and what kind of restrictions we faced.
134.title: AMP as PWA Case Study

135.description: Kotlin is a very flexible programming language. You have a chance to write more readable and good-looking code. The only limit is your imagination and creativity. I'll show you some examples which are really handsome :)
135.title: Handsome codes with Kotlin

136.description: You can now speed through online checkout on many of your favorite apps and websites with a few quick clicks.
136.title: Pay with Google and speed through checkout

137.description: Open Source projelerin ne anlama geldiği, önemi hakkında konuşacağım. Bunun dışında katıldığım Google Code-In ve Google Summer of Code hakkında genel bilgi vereceğim.
137.title: Open Source ve Google Code-In

138.description: What is the ultimate hack of our lives? What is the one thing that we strive to learn the most about? What is the thing that will truly unlock our potentials? This talk is a demonstration of an open-source Brain-Computer Interface that is completely developed with JavaScript, from the ground up, using neural networks and signal processing. The speaker hits the stage with a wireless EEG headset, shows how to read signals from the brain in JavaScript using native C++ Node.js modules over USB, and the implementation in Electron, including tweeting with brain signals.
138.title: Brain: The ultimate hack

140.description: Google Cloud Platform (GCP) offers many options for storing your data. From Cloud Storage (Multi-regional, Nearline, Coldline) to the various database services (Cloud Datastore, Cloud SQL, Cloud Bigtable) and data warehousing (BigQuery), learn about the most common workloads and common patterns for data storage.
140.title: Choosing Google Cloud Storage Services

speakers.bio: As an engineer who is in love with the coolest new technology, I thrive by connecting to other developers who share similar passions. My team is behind all the rich, technical content on developers.google.com.  I act as an advocate for third party developers’ needs within Google and passionate evangelists for Google technologies in the outside world. I love connecting with other developers and partners; people who enjoy teaching, speaking or writing about cutting-edge technologies. By working closely with third party developers who are building applications and businesses that showcase Google’s developer platforms, I grow and support the developer community, teaching and supporting developers around MENA region.

speakers.bio: Mehmet N. Aydin, Associate Professor at Management Information Systems Department and the director of INEO Technology Transfer Office at Kadir Has University, Istanbul has provided organizations with proven expertise in the emerging field of cloud computing, Corporate Innovations Systems and Technology Management, Network Science. He holds PhD in Management Information Systems from University of Twente, The Netherlands. Dr. Aydin worked at the Institute for Innovation and Technology Management, Ryerson University, Toronto, Canada and at the Department of Information Systems and Change Management at University of Twente, the Netherlands. He has published over 50 articles as journal papers (e.g., Journal of Database Management, Information Frontiers, Journal of Enterprise Management), book chapters (e.g., Springer series on Lecture Notes in Computer Science) conference proceedings (IFIP 8.1, CAISE). His contribution to the research field of method engineering is laudable and cited in various studies. He can be reached at mehmet.aydin@khas.edu.tr.

speakers.bio:
Lemi Orhan Ergin has been working as Agile Software Craftsman and Agile Practice Lead at iyzico. He completed his undergraduate and graduate degree in Computer Engineering department of Marmara University. He has been actively developing software since 2001. He has worked as software architect, software craftsman, technical leader, team leader, technical coordinator, Scrum Master and Agile coach in dozens of software projects at BYM, GittiGidiyor / eBay and Sony. As a managing partner in ACM, he has provided consulting services to dozens of companies. He has led the establishment of agile software cultures, continuity and sustainability in software teams.

He has been sharing his experience about Agile / Scrum, Kanban, Management 3.0, Git, ALM Processes, TDD, Clean Code, Agile Engineering Practices and Software Craftsmanship with hundreds of professionals. He has been a national and international conference speaker. Slides of his talks has been displayed more than 1 million times on the Internet.

He works voluntarily in software communities. He is the founder of the Software Craftsmanship Turkey community. He had been the leader of the community and the product owner of Agile Turkey Summit and CraftSummit conferences for two years.

speakers.bio: Erdem Demir is a a software engineer and technical consultant.  Erdem holds a PhD from University of California in Software Engineering, he has over 10 years of experience in building complex software systems and technical consulting.  He worked as a Software Engineer for Google from 2007 to 2011, worked as a Software Architect for Ericsson between 2011 and 2013, and has been working as a Publishers Technical Consultant with Google since 2013.

speakers.bio: Born in 1990 in Mardin, Kadir Caner Ergün graduated from İstanbul Computer Education and Instructional Technology Major. He worked in Düş Fırçası,Sevgilikitabi.com,Infovas as a PHP & Android Developer. Kadir Caner Ergün has been working at Mynet A.S as Full Stack Developer since 2016. He has participated in various projects such as Mynet CMS integration and mobile AMP, etc.  At the same time he is Istanbul University Informatics Master Student.

speakers.bio: Engin Deveci is a solution architect and technology consultant. He holds a PhD from Boğaziçi University in Computer Science and has 10+ years of experience in designing, developing and delivering telecommunications, mobile and web solutions. He worked as a developer/architect for Telsim/Oksijen, Ericsson and for his own startup. Engin has been working as a technology consultant with Google since 2017.

speakers.bio: Kaan is a mobile software engineer at MyDrive Solutions in London, UK. As an active community builder, he has co-organized a lot of developer events in Turkey and the UK such as DevFests, Android Developer Days’, Android Study Jams, etc. Besides being a Google Developer Group (GDG) London co-organizer, he is a Google Top Contributor (TC) and a Google Local Guide. Kaan is passionate about exploring new technologies and traveling around the world.
